questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with severe rheumatoid arthritis has worsening joint pain, swelling, and stiffness despite taking methotrexate and an NSAID. The rheumatologist decides to add a corticosteroid to control inflammation. Which corticosteroid is the most appropriate, considering potency, duration, and side effects?
questions.explanation:
Duration of Action

Glucocorticoid

Potency

Effects/Uses

Short (8-12 hrs)

Hydrocortisone

(Option A)

Low

Physiological replacement therapy, adrenal insufficiency, anti-inflammatory

Intermediate (12-36 hrs)

Cortisone

Anti-inflammatory, rheumatic disorders

Prednisone

Intermediate

Anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, rheumatic disorders, asthma, autoimmune diseases.

Prednisolone

(Option C)

Intermediate to Long

Methylprednisolone

Intermediate to High

Anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, severe inflammatory conditions, multiple sclerosis.

Long

(36-72 hrs)

Dexamethasone

(Option D)

High

  

Anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, severe inflammatory conditions, cerebral edema.

Betamethasone (Option B)

Fludrocortisone

Mineralocorticoid activity, adrenal insufficiency, salt-wasting disorders.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is hospitalised at 30 weeks with PPROM. To reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm infants, the obstetrician decides to administer corticosteroids. Which corticosteroid regimen is recommended to promote fetal lung maturity?

options.label: A
options.text: Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses

options.label: B
options.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrocortisone 250 mg intravenous (IV) every 6 hours for 4 doses

questions.correct_answer: A. Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for 2 doses
questions.explanation:
• Betamethasone 12 mg IM every 24 hours for a total of 2 doses.

(OR)

  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses (Option B)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with severe systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) involving multiple organs presents with fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and signs of lupus nephritis. The rheumatologist plans high-dose corticosteroids to induce remission. What is the preferred dose of corticosteroid?
questions.correct_answer: B. Methylprednisolone 1 g intravenous (IV) for 3 days
questions.explanation:
Corticosteroids

Adverse Effects

Hydrocortisone

(Option D)

Adrenal suppression, increased risk of infections, fluid retention, hypertension.

Cortisone

Prednisone

(Option A)

Weight gain, osteoporosis, diabetes mellitus, cushingoid features, skin changes.

Prednisolone

Methylprednisolone

(Option B)

Hypertension, hyperglycemia, electrolyte imbalances (hypokalemia), psychiatric disturbances

Dexamethasone

(Option C)

Psychiatric disturbances, cushingoid features, increased risk of infections.

Betamethasone

Fludrocortisone

Hypertension, edema, hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a widespread, itchy, erythematous rash on his arms, legs, and trunk has not found relief with over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream. Suspecting atopic dermatitis, the dermatologist prescribes a more potent topical steroid. Which topical steroid is most appropriate for this patient's condition and age?
questions.explanation:
Topical Steroid

Typical Dose

Efficacy

Uses

Hydrocortisone

(Option A)

0.5% - 2.5% cream/ointment

Mild

Mild inflammatory skin conditions in sensitive areas.

Triamcinolone

(Option B)

0.025% - 0.1% cream/ointment

Moderate

Atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, psoriasis.

Betamethasone

(Option C)

0.05% - 0.1% cream/ointment

High

Severe inflammatory skin conditions, refractory cases.

Clobetasol

(Option D)

0.05% cream/ointment

Very high

Severe, recalcitrant cases, short-term use only.

Fluocinolone

0.025% - 0.2% cream/ointment

Moderate-high

Atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, lichen planus.

Mometasone

0.1% cream/ointment

  

Atopic dermatitis, eczema, psoriasis

Fluticasone

0.005% - 0.05% cream/ointment

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with severe nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps, fatigue, dizziness, dehydration, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Labs show hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. Which medication is most appropriate for his condition?
Which of the following is Diethylstilbestrol (DES) classified as?
questions.explanation:
Natural Estrogens

Steroidal Synthetic Estrogens

Nonsteroidal Synthetic Estrogens
  • Estradiol
  • Estrone
  • Estriol
  • Ethinylestradiol
  • Mestranol
  • Tibolone
  • Diethylstilbestrol
  • Hexestrol
  • Dienestrol

Aspect

Effect of Estrogen

Reproductive Organ Regulation

Governs growth and function of female reproductive organs and menstrual cycles.

Secondary Sexual Characteristics

Prompts development of female secondary sexual characteristics during puberty.

Bone Density Maintenance

It helps maintain bone density by inhibiting bone breakdown and promoting bone formation.

Cardiovascular

It improves cardiovascular health by regulating cholesterol levels.

Brain Function

Influences cognitive function, memory, mood regulation, and emotional well-being.

Skin and Hair Health

Contributes to skin thickness, elasticity, hydration, and hair growth.

Urinary Tract Integrity

It supports the integrity of urinary tract tissues and may prevent urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with a history of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. She is prescribed tamoxifen as part of her adjuvant therapy regimen to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of tamoxifen?

options.label: A
options.text: It acts as a direct agonist on estrogen receptors in breast tissue.

options.label: B
options.text: It acts as an antagonist on estrogen receptors in breast tissue.

options.label: D
options.text: It stimulates progesterone receptors in breast tissue.

questions.correct_answer: B. It acts as an antagonist on estrogen receptors in breast tissue.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Tamoxifen

Raloxifene

Mechanism of Action

Estrogen Receptor (ER) Antagonist

↓

Binds to ER

↓

Tissue-specific effects such as :

  • Antagonist in breast tissue (prevents estrogen binding).
  • Agonist in bone and cardiovascular tissues (estrogen-like effects)

Clinical Use
  • Drug of choice for ER-positive breast cancer.
  • Decrease the risk of contralateral breast cancer.
  • Prevention of breast cancer.
  • Treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.

Side Effects
  • Increased risk of endometrial cancer.
  • Thromboembolism, hot flashes, depression, hepatotoxicity, cataracts.
  • No increased risk of endometrial cancer.
  • Hot flashes, depression. Thromboembolism are seen

Drug Interactions
  • It should not be combined with fluoxetine and other SSRIs.
  • SSRIs inhibit the CYP2D6 enzyme, essential for converting tamoxifen into its active form, endoxifen.
  • This interaction may lower endoxifen levels, diminishing tamoxifen's effectiveness against estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.
  • No significant drug interactions.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with infertility. She has irregular menstrual cycles and is suspected of having anovulation. She was started on Clomiphene citrate. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.label: A
options.text: Binds to estrogen receptors, exerting agonistic effects in breast tissues.

options.label: B
options.text: Acts as a SERM, exerting antagonist effects in the pituitary.

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits aromatase enzyme activity, reducing estrogen synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Stimulates gonadotropin secretion by blocking estrogenic feedback inhibition of the pituitary.

questions.correct_answer: D. Stimulates gonadotropin secretion by blocking estrogenic feedback inhibition of the pituitary.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Clomiphene Citrate

Mechanism of Action

Blocking of estrogen receptors in hypothalamus by Clomiphene citrate

↓

Removal of estrogen feedback inhibition

↓

Increased GnRH secretion from the hypothalamus

↓

Increased FSH and LH secretion from the pituitary

↓

Stimulation of ovarian follicle growth

↓

Ovulation

Uses
  • Treatment of infertility due to failure of ovulation, often in cases of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) or unexplained infertility.
  • Used in assisted reproductive technology (ART) procedures.
  • Treatment of oligozoospermia in men, where it increases gonadotropin secretion, promoting spermatogenesis and testosterone secretion.

Adverse Effects
  • Polycystic ovaries
  • Multiple pregnancies
  • Hot flashes
  • Vertigo
  • Allergic dermatitis
  • Increased risk of ovarian tumour

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, whose half-life is 46 hours, primarily acts as an aromatase inhibitor?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Mechanism of Action

Use

Adverse Effects

Letrozole

(Option C)

Inhibition of Aromatase Enzyme

↓

Reduction in Peripheral Estrogen Synthesis

↓

Decreased Estrogen Levels in circulation.

 

The half-life of Letrozole is 46 hours

Breast cancer treatment

Ovulation induction.

Hot flashes, joint pain, bone loss.

Clomiphene

(Option A)

Blocks Estrogen Receptors in the Hypothalamus

↓

Prevents Negative Feedback Inhibition

↓

Increased Release of Gonadotropins (FSH and LH) from Pituitary

↓

Stimulation of Ovulation

Ovulation induction.

Infertility in women.

Hot flashes, gastric upset, multiple pregnancies.

Tamoxifen

(Option B)

Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM)

  • Antagonist in breast tissue.
  • Agonist in bone and cardiovascular tissues.

Breast cancer treatment and prophylaxis.

Endometrial hyperplasia, risk of endometrial carcinoma, and venous thromboembolism.

Fulvestrant

(Option D)

Binding to Estrogen Receptors (ER)

↓

ER Degradation and Downregulation

↓

Inhibition of ER Signaling Pathways

↓

Decreased Estrogen

Advanced breast cancer treatment.

Injection site reactions, nausea, liver impairment.

questions.text: Which progestin type is characterized by both estrogenic and androgenic actions?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Actions

Side Effects

Medroxyprogesterone acetate

No significant estrogenic activity.

 

Nausea, breast tenderness, menstrual changes, headache, abdominal pain, fatigue, dizziness.

Levonorgestrel

Has minimal estrogenic activity.

Norethindrone

Exhibits weak estrogenic and androgenic activity.

Similar to medroxyprogesterone acetate, but with the addition of possible androgenic side effects such as acne, hirsutism, and changes in libido.

Cyproterone

Has antiandrogenic activity: Blocks androgen receptors and inhibits testosterone production.

Menstrual changes, breast tenderness, weight changes, mood changes, decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, depression (rare but severe).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with endometriosis comes to the clinic as her symptoms have not been relieved by first-line drugs. Which of the following drugs can be tried to provide relief to her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Androgenic Drugs

Uses

Methyltestosterone

(Option C)
  • Androgen replacement therapy in hypogonadism
  • Hypopituitarism
  • Testicular failure
  • Idiopathic male infertility
  • Delayed puberty in boys

Testosterone undecanoate
  • Cachexia in HIV or cancer patients.

Anabolic steroid

  • Nandrolone (Option A)
  • Oxymetholone
  • Stanozolol
  • Bodybuilding
  • Catabolic states such as acute illness, major surgery
  • Malignancy associated anemia

questions.text: A 70-year-old man who was diagnosed with metastatic prostatic cancer was started on combined androgen deprivation (CAD) therapy. Which of the following anti-androgenic drugs are used in combined androgen deprivation to prevent initial flare-ups due to initial LH and testosterone production due to GnRH agonist use?
questions.explanation:
Anti androgenic Drugs

MOA

Uses

Side effects

Flutamide

(Option A)

Non-steroidal androgen receptor blocker

It also increases LH secretion.
  • CAB therapy for metastatic prostate cancer.
  • Female hirsutism.
  • Hepatotoxic
  • Gynecomastia
  • Breast tenderness

Bicalutamide

Same as Flutamide but more potent and has a longer half-life
  • Metastatic prostate cancer
  • Less hepatotoxic
  • Hot flashes
  • Chills
  • Oedema

Cyproterone acetate

(Option D)

Weak androgen receptor blocker with progestational activity. It suppresses LH secretion.
  • Precocious puberty in boys
  • Female hirsutism
  • Oral contraception in combination with ethinylestradiol
  • Hepatotoxic

Ketoconazole

(Option C)

Inhibits steroidogenic CYP450 enzyme, thus inhibiting steroid production

Antifungal agent

Antiandrogenic effects include gynaecomastia and ↓ libido.

Finasteride

(Option B)

5 alpha-reductase inhibitor thus reduces the conversion of testosterone to DHT.
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia.
  • Androgenic alopecia .

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the dermatologist with complaints of progressive thinning of hair for 3 years. His family has a history of male-pattern baldness. A diagnosis of androgenic alopecia was made, for which he was prescribed topical Minoxidil. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.label: A
options.text: Blockade of 5 alpha-reductase enzyme, thus preventing DHT formation.

options.label: B
options.text: Ornithine decarboxylase enzyme inhibitor, which is found in the hair follicles.

options.label: C
options.text: Blockade of androgenic receptors along with progestational activity.

options.label: D
options.text: K+ channel opening leads to vasodilation of microvessels around the hair follicles.

questions.correct_answer: D. K+ channel opening leads to vasodilation of microvessels around the hair follicles.
questions.explanation:
Options

Description

Finasteride/Dutasteride

(Option A)

MOA

5α reductase enzyme inhibitor, which prevents the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

Uses
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia.
  • Androgenic alopecia (oral form and not topical as a topical agent)

Eflornithine

(Option B)

MOA

It inhibits the ornithine decarboxylase enzyme found in the hair follicle, thus slowing hair growth and serving as a hair depilator.

Uses

Topical agent to remove excessive facial hair in Hirsutism in females,

Cyproterone acetate

(Option C)

MOA
  • The weak blocker of androgenic receptors with progestational activity.
  • It also suppresses LH secretion.

Uses
  • Female hirsutism.
  • Precocious puberty in boys.
  • Inappropriate sexual behavior in men.
  • Oral contraception in combination with ethinylestradiol.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman complains of hot flashes that interfere with her daily activities and sleep. Considering her history of recurrent thromboembolism, which of the following drugs would be appropriate for the treatment of her post-menopausal hot flashes?

A 48-year-old man comes to the OPD due to his inability to maintain a penile erection during sexual intercourse. He was prescribed Sildenafil to help with his erectile dysfunction. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 enzyme, thus increasing cytosolic cGMP levels.

options.label: B
options.text: Central alpha-2 agonist, reducing sympathetic outflow and causing vasodilation.

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-3 enzyme, thus increasing cytosolic cAMP levels.

options.label: D
options.text: Peripheral alpha-blocker reduces vascular resistance and improve blood flow.

questions.correct_answer: A. Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 enzyme, thus increasing cytosolic cGMP levels.
questions.explanation:
Sildenafil

↓

Inhibits phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) enzyme

↓

Prevents cGMP degradation

↓

Increases cytosolic cGMP levels

↓

Prolongs activation of GMP-dependent protein kinase

↓

Inhibits myosin light chain kinase dephosphorylation

↓

Smooth muscle relaxation in the corpus cavernosum

↓

Increased blood flow

↓

Sustained penile erection

  • Blue-green colour blindness
  • Non Arteritic ischaemic optic neuropathy (NA ION)
  • Priapism
  • Flushing
  • Nasal congestion
  • Dyspepsia
  • Hypotension
